Vibration of a Circular Membrane Part 2: Solving the Wave Equation

Apr 18, 2019

Last time we ended with the Laplacian of polar coordinates, namely

In this post, I will introduce you Wave equation, 2-dim wave equation and the solution for the case where . i.e., is circularly symmetric (radially symmetric).

1.Two Dimensional Wave Equation

How would one describe the movement of a wave? More explicitly, suppose that you have an infinitely thin rubber cloak. This piece of rubber is extremely

precise and tensionly even, so that every molecule(or, infinitesimal amount of local part of the cloak) of the rubber is being pulled by the same force, every time, evenly.

Notice that if the rubber cloak changes its form with ‘‘meaningfully big amount’’, the tension would not be even, thus we need the assumption that total changes of the wave as time passes is not large.

For every point of the cloak, it moves only if there are some curvature at that point. We can think of this as some kind of a trampoline, since trampoline only pushes things up when it has a positive second derivative(i.e., positive curvature). Also, one can educatedly guess that the second derivative of the trampoline is proportional to the amount of force it will provide

upward. (You can get this result much more rigorously, but that’s rather simple and you probably already know why it works.) Therefore, one has

where is force (more precisely, force per area) caused by the rubber cloak in upward direction. We will use the famous Newton’s law to get

This is the Two Dimensional Wave equation.

2. Radially Symmetric, Finite Wave Equation

Taking the Laplacian for polar coordinate, we have

Since we are considering radially symmetric case, we have

We will now consider as a function with two variables, and .

But this is not enough to fully solve the wave equation. As all differential equations, one needs initial conditions and boundary conditions. In this case, we will have a condition that describe

a finite wave. That is;

Also, the starting state of the wave is also known, because we need at least somewhere to start with.

So we know the position and velocity of the overall cloak at time .

Now to solve the equation, we will use separation of variables .

The left hand side and the right hand side has the equality, but with different variables. This must mean that they equal to some constant . The reason why it is negative is because we expect

non-trivial solutions, and that if it is positive, for fixed we have exponential solution. This is contradictory because physically we expect finite solution for arbitrary given time(of course,

more rigorous argument can be made. We will not mention it now.Perhaps later? lol). We now have full description of equations we need to solve.

3. Bessel Functions

The first equation is strange. Specifically, the differential equation

is not the kind that we know of. We can assume it’s existence and use Taylor expansion

Indeed, such function exists and are called ‘‘Bessel Functions’’. There are two solution to above differential equation, and one can easily see that by the Taylor expansion,

since the parity of the coefficients’ index doesn’t change. There are actually a lot of different kinds of Bessel function and we will talk about it in different post.

Let’s just realize that these are called ‘‘Bessel functions of order 0 of the first and second kind’’. Just in case you are unfamiliar with function , they satisfy

where is Eular- Mascheroni constant.

We now have the solution for part. Namely that

But unfortunately, function is unbounded near 0. You can see this by the part in the formula above. Thus, we are left with the first kind.
